dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A young boy, dressed in a school uniform and cap, fidgets adjusts his tie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now remember, keep your shoulders back. A student opens up a case and removes a set of bagpipes. boy and his brother line up for a photograph

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, put your arm around your brother. That's it. And breathe in. The young boy blinks as the flash goes off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, one more. An old man lights a single candle. A teacher goes over th man's duties.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now just to review, you're going to follow along the procession until you get to the headmaster. At that point he will indicate to you to light the candles of the boys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right boys, let's settle down. The various boys, including NEIL, KNOX, and CAMERON, line banners. Ahead of them is the old man, followed by the bo bagpipes with the two youngest boys at the front.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Banners up. The boys hoist the banners and the bagpipes begin to play small group marches out of the room and down a set of sta church. The pews are filled with students and parents whi teachers, all dressed in robes, are seated at the front o behind the headmaster. The boys break off to either side at the front of the chu bagpipes cease and the headmaster, MR. NOLAN, walks over man carrying the candle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ladies and gentlemen, boys, the light of knowledge. An organ begins to play as the old man goes forward with to the young boys in the front pew. Each boy is holding a he bends over to light the first one. Each boy in turn li candle of the boy next to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One hundred years ago, in 1859, 41 boys sat in this room and were asked the same question that greets you at the start of each semester. Gentlemen, what are the four pillars? All throughout the pews, uniformed boys rise to their fee is not wearing a uniform, is urged by his father to stand

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tradition, honor, discipline, excellence. The boys quickly return to their seats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In her first year, Welton Academy graduated five students. Last year we graduated fifty-one. And more than seventy-five percent of those went on to the Ivy League. This, this kind of accomplishment is the result of fervent dedication to the principles taught here. This is why you parents have been sending us your sons. This is why we are the best preparatory school in the United States. Mr. Nolan soaks up the applause from the audience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As you know, our beloved Mr. Portius of the English department retired last term. You will have the opportunity later to meet his replacement, Mr. John Keating, himself a graduate of this school. And who, for the past several years, has been teaching at the highly regarded Chester School in London. The crowd applauds once again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The school lawn is a filled with luggage, students, and p about in every direction.

dialogues.speaker: INT CHURCH ENTRANCE
dialogues.text: Mr Nolan stands by the entrance, speaking with each famil

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glad you could come by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thrilling ceremony as usual Dr. Nolan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've been away too long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello Dr. Nolan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good to have you back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is our youngest, Todd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Anderson.You have some big shoes to fill, young man. Your brother was one of our finest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. Todd and his parents leave while others file past Mr. Nol

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lovely ceremony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. So glad you liked it. MR PERRY approaches with his son Neil. He shakes Mr. Nola

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gale

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good to see you again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello Mr. Nolan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neil. We expect great things from you this year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well he won't disappoint us. Right Neil?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll do my best sir.

dialogues.speaker: EXT SCHOOL GROUNDS
dialogues.text: A bell tolls. Parents begin wishing their boys farewell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, come on son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chin up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No tears now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chin up. Another boy hugs his mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to go here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You be a good boy and do your lessons.

dialogues.speaker: EXT SCHOOL GROUNDS
dialogues.text: Neil emerges from a building and sees Todd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, I hear we're gonna be roommates. He shakes Todd's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Neil Perry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Todd Anderson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why'd you leave Balincrest?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My brother went here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, so you're that Anderson.

dialogues.speaker: INT DORMATORY
dialogues.text: DR. HAGER is standing in his room doorway while SPAZ and going over some last minute precautions over the boy's al father hands Hager various bottles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is for sinuses. Oh, and if he can't swallow you give him one of these. And if he had trouble breathing you can give him some of those.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right fine. Dr. Hager takes the bottles and quickly backs into his ro the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to son)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you remember your vaporizer? SPAZ

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I put it in my room. Spaz's father tries to say something else to Dr. Hager bu has already gone.

dialogues.speaker: INT HALLWAY
dialogues.text: Neil pushes his way through a crowd of boys, carrying two he enters his room, Knox quickly passes by. KNOX

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, how's it going Neil? NEIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey Knox. Cameron comes by and leans against the doorway. CAMERON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neil, study group tonight? NEIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, sure. CAMERON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Business as usual, huh? Hey, I hear you got the new kid. Looks like a stiff! He begins laughing when he notices Todd coming into the r CAMERON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oops! Cameron quickly leaves. Neil tries to keep from laughing the room and sets his luggage down on his bed. NEIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, don't mind Cameron. He was born with his foot in his mouth. You know what I mean? He pulls some papers from his blazer pocket and playfully across the back with it. CHARLIE comes to the door with a smug expression on his f MEEKS are close behind him. He points at Neil CHARLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rumor has it, you did summer school. NEIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yep. Chemistry. My father thought I should get ahead. How was your summer Slick? CHARLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keen. The boys enter the room. Charlie turns around and looks a just entering.  CHARLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meeks. Door. Closed. MEEKS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir. NEIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, what are the four pillars? BOYS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Travesty. Horror. Decadence. Excrement. Charlie makes himself comfortable on Neil's bed and light Meanwhile, Todd is by his bed unpacking his luggage. CHARLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, study group. Meeks aced Latin. I didn't quite flunk English. So, if you want, we've got our study group. NEIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. Cameron asked me too. Anyone mind including him? CHARLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmm, what's his specialty, boot-licking? NEIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, he's your roommate. CHARLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not my fault. Meeks seems to notice Todd for the first time. MEEKS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I'm sorry, my name is Steven Meeks. Neil quickly gets up from his spot by the window. NEIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, this is Todd Anderson. Todd turns around and shakes hands with Meeks. MEEKS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice to meet you. TODD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice to meet you. CHARLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie Dalton. Charlie continues to lay on the bed, looking smug. Knox e KNOX

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Knox Overstreet. NEIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Todd's brother was Jeffrey Anderson. CHARLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah, sure. Valedictorian. National merit scholar.  MEEKS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh well, welcome to Hell-ton. CHARLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's every bit as tough as they say, unless you're a genius like Meeks. MEEKS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He flatters me. That's why I help him with Latin. CHARLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And English, and Trig. Charlie begins coughing. There is a knock at the door. Ch stamps out his cigarette on the floor and Neil tries to w from the air. NEIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's open. The door opens and Mr. Perry walks into the room. Neil qu the window. NEIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father, I thought you'd gone. The other boys stand up when he enters. BOYS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Perry. MR PERRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep your seats fellows, keep your seats. Neil, I've just spoken to Mr. Nolan. I think that you're taking too many extra curricular activities this semester, and I've decided that you should drop the school annual. NEIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I'm the assistant editor this year. MR PERRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I'm sorry Neil. NEIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Father, I can't. It wouldn't be fair. MR PERRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fellas, would you excuse us for a moment? Mr. Perry walks towards the door and Neil hesitantly foll pauses by the door and smiles to the other boys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The smile has gone from Mr. Perry's face. He grabs a hold MR PERRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you ever dispute me in public. Do you understand? NEIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father, I wasn't disputing- MR PERRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After you've finished medical school and you're on your o can do as you damn well please. But until then, you do as Is that clear? NEIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir. I'm sorry. MR PERRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know how much this means to your mother, don't you? NEIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir. You know me, always taking on too much. MR PERRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that's my boy. Now listen, you need anything, you let us know, huh? NEIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir. Mr. Perry slaps his son on the shoulder and leaves. Neil back against the wall as the other boys emerge from the r CHARLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why doesn't he let you do what you want? KNOX

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah Neil, tell him off. It couldn't get any worse. NEIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, that's rich. Like you guys tell your parents off, Mr. Future Lawyer and Mr. Future Banker. CHARLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, so I don't like it any more than you do. NEIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well just don't tell me how to talk to my father. You guys are the same way. KNOX

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, all right, Jesus. So what are you going to do? NEIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What I have to do. Drop the annual. CHARLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I wouldn't lose much sleep over it. It's just a bunch of jerks trying to impress Nolan. NEIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care. I don't give a damn about any of it. MEEKS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, uh, Latin, eight o' clock in my room? NEIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. MEEKS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Todd, you're welcome to join us. KNOX

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, come along pal. Todd looks up from his desk where he is setting his alarm TODD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A clock bell chimes five o'clock. Enormous flocks of bird disturbed by the noise, take to the sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sound of squawking birds merges into the sound of noi descend the stairs in a long spiralling line. MR. MCALLISTER tries to make it upstairs against the stea MCALLISTER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slow down boys, slow down you horrible phalanx of pubescense.

dialogues.speaker: INT CHEMISTRY LAB
dialogues.text: A teacher walks up and down the aisles, handing out books TEACHER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pick three laboratory experiments from the project list and report on them every five weeks. The first twenty questions at the end of chapter one are due tomorrow. The students let out a collective groan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. McAllister paces back and forth in front of the black the students to repeat everything he says. MCALLISTER (students repeat after each word.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agricolam. Agricola. Agricolae. Agricolarum. Agricolis. Agricolas. Agrilcolis. Again, please. Agricola.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Hager walks up the classroom aisles with his arms beh HAGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your study of trigonometry requires absolute precision. Anyone failing to turn in any homework assignment will be penalized one point off their final grade. Let me urge you now not to test me on this point.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Students enter Keating's classroom, talking and acting up glances out from his room off to one side. KNOX

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey Spaz, Spaz. Spaz turns around in time to be hit by a ball of crumpled while Cameron smacks him on the shoulder. CAMERON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brain damage. The students quickly quiet down as Keating emerges from t whistling the 1812 Overture. He walks up the length of th out the door without a word. The students look around at uncertain of what to do. Keating pokes his head back in t KEATING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well come on. He gestures them to follow and the students, after some h their books and follow Keating out into the main entrance

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keating stands before the school's trophy cabinets and wa the boys arrive. KEATING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Oh Captain, My Captain" who knows where that comes from? Todd looks up as if he knows the answer, but says nothing nose a little too close to Meeks for his liking. KEATING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not a clue? It's from a poem by Walt Whitman about Mr. Abraham Lincoln. Now in this class you can call me Mr. Keating. Or, if you're slightly more daring, Oh Captain, My Captain. The students laugh slightly. KEATING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now let me dispel a few rumors so they don't fester into facts. Yes, I too attended Hell-ton and survived. And no, at that time I was not the mental giant you see before you. I was the intellectual equivalent of a ninety-eight pound weakling. I would go to the beach and people would kick copies of Byron in my face. The boys laugh once again, while Cameron, obviously tryin this down, looks around confusedly. Keating looks down at hand. KEATING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, MrВ… Pitts. That's a rather unfortunate name. Mr. Pitts, where are you? Pitts raises his hand while everyone around him snickers. KEATING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Pitts, would you open your hymnal to page 542 and rea stanza of the poem you find there? PITTS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "To the virgins, to make much of time"? KEATING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, that's the one. Somewhat appropriate, isn't it. PITTS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Gather ye rosebuds while ye may, old time is still a flying, and this same flower that smiles today, tomorrow will be dying." KEATING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you Mr. Pitts. "Gather ye rosebuds while ye may." The Latin term for that sentiment is Carpe Diem. Now who knows what that means? Meeks immediately puts his hand up. MEEKS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carpe Diem. That's "seize the day." KEATING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very good, Mr.- MEEKS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meeks. KEATING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meeks. Another unusual name. Seize the day. Gather ye rosebuds while ye may. Why does the writer use these lines? CHARLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because he's in a hurry. KEATING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, ding! Keating slams his hand down on an imaginary buzzer. KEATING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you for playing anyway. Because we are food for worms lads. Because, believe it or not, each and every one of us in this room is one day going to stop breathing, turn cold, and die.  Keating turns towards the trophy cases, filled with troph and team pictures. KEATING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now I would like you to step forward over here and peruse some of the faces from the past. You've walked past them many times. I don't think you've really looked at them. The students slowly gather round the cases and Keating mo KEATING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're not that different from you, are they? Same haircuts. Full of hormones, just like you. Invincible, just like you feel. The world is their oyster. They believe they're destined for great things, just like many of you. Their eyes are full of hope, just like you. Did they wait until it was too late to make from their lives even one iota of what they were capable? Because you see gentlmen, these boys are now fertilizing daffodils. But if you listen real close, you can hear them whisper their legacy to you. Go on, lean in. The boys lean in and Keating hovers over Cameron's should KEATING (whispering in a gruff voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carpe. Cameron looks over his shoulder with an aggravated expres KEATING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hear it? (whispering again)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carpe. Carpe Diem. Seize the day boys, make your lives extraordinary. The boys stare at the faces in the cabinet in silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys emerge from the school, loaded down with numerou PITTS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was weird. NEIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But different. KNOX

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spooky if you ask me. CAMERON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Think he'll test us on that stuff? CHARLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on Cameron, don't you get anything? CAMERON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A coach sticks his head around the corner into the room. COACH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go boys, hustle up in here. That means you Dalton. Meeks emerges from the showers, drying himself off. MEEKS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, who's up for a trig study group tonight guys? PITTS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me. NEIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me. CHARLIE (still annoyed by what the coach said)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? KNOX

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't make it guys. I have to have dinner at the Danburry's house. PITTS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Danburry's? Who are the Danburry's? CAMERON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big alumns. How'd you swing that? KNOX

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Friends of my Dad's. They're probably in their nineties or something. CHARLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ooh! NEIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything's better than Hell-ton hash. CHARLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll second that. KNOX

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah we'll see. Neil approaches Todd, who's been sitting by the window st floor. Neil snaps his fingers to get Todd's attention.  NEIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, you coming to the study group tonight? TODD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, no, no I, uh, I've got some history I wanna do. NEIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suit yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Todd is seated at his desk. He scrawls "CARPE DIEM" acros of his notebook. He looks at it for a few moments before and opening up his Chemistry book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hager comes down the stairs. Knox is looking at one of th on the walls. HAGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ready Overstreet? Knox reluctantly follows after Dr. Hager. KNOX

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ready to go sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car leaves Welton and drives towards the Danburry's h

dialogues.speaker: INT / EXT DANBURRY'S HOUSE
dialogues.text: The doorbell rings. MRS DANBURRY (O.S.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chet, can you get that? CHET (O.S.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't, Mom. CHRIS (O.S.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll get it. The door opens and Knox is awe-struck by the beautiful gi has answered the door. CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I help you? Knox manages to break out of his daze. KNOX

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. Knox Overstreet. Uh, Dr. Hager. CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. KNOX

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the Danburry's, right? CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you here to see Chet? KNOX

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Danburry? Chris begins to laugh as Mrs. Danburry arrives behind her CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. MRS DANBURRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry. Thank you Chris. I'm Mrs. Danburry. You must be Knox. KNOX

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. MRS DANBURRY (to Dr. Hager)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back by nine. (to Knox)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please come in. CHET (O.S.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris, come on, what are you doing? CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chet, I'm coming. Knox enters the house, his mind still hung up on Chris as comes out of the living room to meet him. MR DANBURRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Knox. How are you? Joe Danburry. KNOX

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice to meet you sir. MR DANBURRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well he's the spitting image of his father, isn't he. How is he? Come on in. CHET (O.S.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris! KNOX

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's great. He just did a big case for GM. CHRIS (O.S.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm coming. MR DANBURRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know where you're headed, like father like son, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Several students are throwing darts at a small rubber ske from the bulletin board. Various students are studying an Meeks and Pitts are sitting at one table working on their Meeks is waving an antenna around with no luck. Pitts poi that he forgot to plug it in. Neil, Cameron, and Charlie their trig homework. CAMERON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just replace these numbers here with "x", for "x" and "y". NEIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. CAMERON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, so what's the problem? Charlie enters the room and closes the door behind him, l against it heavily. CHARLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How was dinner? KNOX

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh? CHARLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How was dinner? KNOX

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terrible. Awful. He leaves the door and sits down with the other boys. CHARLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? What happened? KNOX

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tonight, I met the most beautiful girl in my entire life. NEIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you crazy? What's wrong with that? KNOX

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's practically engaged. To Chet Danburry. CHARLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That guy could eat a football. PITTS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's too bad. KNOX

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too bad? It's worse than too bad Pitsie, it's a tragedy. A girl this beautiful in love with such a jerk. PITTS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the good ones go for jerks, you know that. CAMERON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ahh, forget her. Open your trig book and try and figure out problem five. KNOX

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: Holy cow. Mr. Hager walks into the room. HAGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right gentlemen, five minutes. Let's go. The students quickly pack up their gear and prepare to le to hide the radio in his lap. Charlie leans in close to K CHARLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you see her naked? KNOX

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very funny Dalton. HAGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That wouldn't be a radio in your lap, would it Mr. Pitts? PITTS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No sir. Science experiment, radar. Meeks holds up the antenna as if demonstrating it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keating sits at his desk at the front of the classroom an of his books. KEATING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, open your text to page twenty-one of the introduction. Mr. Perry, will you read the opening paragraph of the preface, entitled "Understanding Poetry"? NEIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Understanding Poetry, by Dr. J. Evans Pritchard, Ph.D. To fully understand poetry, we must first be fluent with its meter, rhyme, and figures of speech. Then ask two questions: One, how artfully has the objective of the poem been rendered, and two, how important is that objective. Question one rates the poem's perfection, question two rates its importance. And once these questions have been answered, determining a poem's greatest becomes a relatively simple matter. Keating gets up from his desk and prepares to draw on the NEIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If the poem's score for perfection is plotted along the horizontal of a graph, and its importance is plotted on the vertical, then calculating the total area of the poem yields the measure of its greatness. Keating draws a corresponding graph on the board and the dutifully copy it down. NEIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sonnet by Byron may score high on the vertical, but only average on the horizontal. A Shakespearean sonnet, on the other hand, would score high both horizontally and vertically, yielding a massive total area, thereby revealing the poem to be truly great. As you proceed through the poetry in this book, practice this rating method. As your ability to evaluate poems in this matter grows, so will - so will your enjoyment and understanding of poetry. Neil sets the book down and takes off his glasses. The st across from him is discretely trying to eat. Keating turn the chalkboard with a smile. KEATING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excrement. That's what I think of Mr. J. Evans Pritchard. We're not laying pipe, we're talking about poetry. Cameron looks down at the graph he copied into his notes scribbles it out. KEATING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, how can you describe poetry like American Bandstand? I like Byron, I give him a 42, but I can't dance to it. Charlie suddenly appear to become interested in the class KEATING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now I want you to rip out that page. The students look at Keating as if he has just gone mad. KEATING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on, rip out the entire page. You heard me, rip it out. Rip it out! Charlie looks around at the others. He then looks down at which consists of drawing breasts. KEATING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on, rip it out. Charlie rips the page out and holds it up. KEATING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you Mr. Dalton. Gentlemen, tell you what, don't just tear out that page, tear out the entire introduction. I want it gone, history. Leave nothing of it. Rip it out. Rip! Begone J. Evans Pritchard, Ph.D. Rip, shred, tear. Rip it out. I want to hear nothing but ripping of Mr. Pritchard. Meeks looks around reluctantly and then finally begins te KEATING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll perforate it, put it on a roll. Keating sees Cameron still hesitating. KEATING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not the bible, you're not going to go to hell for this. Go on, make a clean tear, I want nothing left of it. Keating goes over to his room. Cameron turns around to Ne CAMERON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We shouldn't be doing this. NEIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rip, rip, rip! Neil makes Cameron turn back around. KEATING (O.S.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rip it out, rip! From outside the classroom, Mr. McAllister hears all the all the students ripping out the pages. He bursts into th MCALLISTER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell is going on here? The boys all turn around in shock. Charlie stuffs a crump mouth. Keating emerges from his room with a waste paper b KEATING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't hear enough rips. MCALLISTER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Keating. KEATING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. McAllister. MCALLISTER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, I- I didn't know you were here. KEATING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am. MCALLISTER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ahh, so you are. Excuse me. Mr. McAllister slowly backs out of the classroom. KEATING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep ripping gentlemen. This is a battle, a war. And the casualties could be your hearts and souls.  Keating holds out the basket to Charlie who spits out a w KEATING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you Mr. Dalton. Armies of academics going forward, measuring poetry. No, we will not have that here. No more of Mr. J. Evans Pritchard. Now in my class you will learn to think for yourselves again. You will learn to savor words and language. No matter what anybody tells you, words and ideas can change the world. I see that look in Mr. Pitt's eye, like nineteenth century literature has nothing to do with going to business school or medical school. Right? Maybe. Mr. Hopkins, you may agree with him,  thinking "Yes, we should simply study our Mr. Pritchard and learn our rhyme and meter and go quietly about the business of achieving other ambitions." I have a little secret for ya. Huddle up. Huddle up!  The boys get up from their seats and gather around Keatin of the class. KEATING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't read and write poetry because it's cute. We read and write poetry because we are members of the human race. And the human race is filled with passion. Medicine, law, business, engineering, these are all noble pursuits, and necessary to sustain life. But poetry, beauty, romance, love, these are what we stay alive for. To quote from Whitman: "O me, o life of the questions of these recurring, of the endless trains of the faithless, of cities filled with the foolish. What good amid these, o me, o life? Answer: that you are here. That life exists, and identity. That the powerful play goes on, and you may contribute a verse. That the powerful play goes on and you may contribute a verse. Keating looks up at Todd. Keating

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What will your verse be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cafeteria is filled with students and teachers standi ALL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For what we are about to receive, may the Lord make us truly grateful. Amen. Mr. Keating and Mr. McAllister are seated next to one ano MCALLISTER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quite an interesting class you gave today, Mr. Keating. KEATING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry if I shocked you, Mr. McAllister. MCALLISTER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, there's no need to apologize. It was very fascinating, misguided though it was. KEATING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think so? MCALLISTER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You take a big risk by encouraging them to be artists John. When they realize they're not Rembrandts, Shakespeares or Mozarts, they'll hate you for it. KEATING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not talking artists George, we're talking free thinkers. MCALLISTER

dialogues.text: Free thinkers at seventeen? KEATING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Funny, I never pegged you as a cynic. MCALLISTER (taken aback by the comment)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not a cynic, a realist. Show me the heart unfettered by foolish dreams, and I'll show you a happy man. KEATING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But only in their dreams can man be truly free. 'Twas always thus, and always thus will be. MCALLISTER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tennyson? KEATING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Keating. Keating winks and Mr. McAllister can't help but laugh.

dialogues.text: That boy there, see me after lunch. Cameron quickly puts the annual away and the others all r

dialogues.text: Keating is walking down towards the lake, whistling the s The boys emerge from the building and chase after him. NEIL

dialogues.text: Oh my God. No, that's not me. Stanley "The Tool" Wilson- Keating crouches down and continues looking through the b KEATING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God. Neil crouches down next to Keating. NEIL

dialogues.text: What was the Dead Poets Society? KEATING

dialogues.text: I doubt the present administration would look too favorably upon that. NEIL

dialogues.text: Why? What was it? KEATING

dialogues.text: Gentlemen, can you keep a secret? NEIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. The other boys crouch down around Keating. KEATING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Dead Poets were dedicated to sucking the marrow out of life. That's a phrase from Thoreau that we'd invoke at the beginning of each meeting. You see we'd gather at the old Indian cave and take turns reading from Thoreau, Whitman, Shelley; the biggies. Even some of our own verse. And in the enchantment of the moment we'd let poetry work its magic. KNOX

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean it was a bunch of guys sitting around reading poetry? KEATING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No Mr. Overstreet, it wasn't just "guys", we weren't a Greek organization, we were romantics. We didn't just read poetry, we let it drip from our tongues like honey. Spirits soared, women swooned, and gods were created, gentlemen, not a bad way to spend an evening eh? Thank you Mr. Perry for this trip down amnesia lane. Burn that, especially my picture. Keating hands the annual back and walks away, whistling o remains crouched. NEIL

Cameron gives a t closes his room door and takes out his cloak and a flashl the flashlight down on the desk, he notices a worn book, Centuries of Verse", sitting there. Opening it up, he see name at the top followed by "Dead Poets". Below the title is written: "To Be Read At The Opening of D.P.S. Meetings several lines from Thoreau, beginning with "I went to the I wanted to live deliberatelyВ…"

dialogues.text: The shadows of hooded figures can be seen moving througho halls.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE

dialogues.text: I hereby reconvene the Dead Poets Society. The boys cheer. NEIL

dialogues.text: Welton chapter. The meetings will be conducted by myself and the other new initiates now present. Todd Anderson, because he prefers not to read, will keep minutes of the meetings. I'll now read the traditional opening message by society member Henry David Thoreau. "I went to the woods because I wanted to live deliberately. I wanted to live deep and suck out all the marrow of life." CHARLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "To put to rout all that was not life, and not, when I had come to die, discover that I had not lived. Several boys whistle softly in reaction to the poem. NEIL

dialogues.text: Neil, lit up by a flashlight, begins to tell everyone a s NEIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was a dark and rainy night, and this old lady, who had a passion for jigsaw puzzles, sat by herself in her house at her table to complete a new jigsaw puzzle. But as she pieced the puzzle together, she realized, to her astonishment, that the image that was formed was her very own room. And the figure in the center of the puzzle, as she completed it, was herself. And with trembling hands, she placed the last four pieces and stared in horror at the face of a demented madman at the window. The last thing that this old lady ever heard was the sound of breaking glass. BOYS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OhhhВ… noВ… NEIL

dialogues.text: The thing with the hand- All the boys react, recalling the story and miming the sc roof of the car. CAMERON

dialogues.text: You memorized a poem?  CHARLIE

dialogues.text: I didn't memorize a poem. Move up. Neil moves to the side as Charlie stands and takes his sp MEEKS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, wow.  CAMERON

dialogues.text: Teach me to love? Go teach thyself more  wit. I, chief professor, am of it. Neil gets up and looks over Charlie's shoulder to see wha reading. CHARLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abraham Cowley. Okay, who's next?  Neil sits reading from the book by flashlight. NEIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: Left, left, left-right-left. Left, left,  left-right-left. Left, halt!  The boys come to a halt. KEATING

dialogues.text: Thank you, gentlemen. If you noticed,  everyone started off with their own  stride, their own pace. Keating begins walking very slowly. KEATING

dialogues.text: Mr. Pitts, taking his time. He knew he'll get there one day. Mr. Cameron, you could see him thinking, "Is this right? It might be right. It might be right. I know that.  Maybe not. I don't know." Keating begins walking with his groin pushed forward. KEATING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Overstreet, driven by deeper force. Yes. We know that. All right. Now, I didn't bring them up here to ridicule them. I brought them up here to illustrate the point of conformity: the difficulty in  maintaining your own beliefs in the face  of others. Now, those of you -- I see  the look in your eyes like, "I would've  walked differently." Well, ask  yourselves why you were clapping. Now,  we all have a great need for acceptance.  But you must trust that your beliefs are  unique, your own, even though others may  think them odd or unpopular, even though  the herd may go, "That's baaaaad." Robert  Frost said, "Two roads diverged in a  wood and I, I took the one less traveled  by, and that has made all the  difference." Now, I want you to find  your own walk right now. Your own way of  striding, pacing. Any direction.  Anything you want. Whether it's proud,  whether it's silly, anything. Gentlemen,  the courtyard is yours. The students begin walking about, some walking casually, making up silly walks. Keating notices that Charlie is st leaning up against one of the pillars. KEATING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have to perform. Just make it  for yourself. Mr. Dalton? You be joining  us?  CHARLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

In fact, its, its shape is,  it's rather aerodynamic, isn't it? I can  feel it. This desk set wants to fly. Neil tosses the desk set lightly in the air. Todd stands and Neil hands him the desk set. NEIL

Whoever the guilty persons are, this is  your only chance to avoid expulsion from  this school. The sound of a phone ringing can be heard. The professors about for its source. dialogues.text: Keating and McAllister are enjoying tea in the small room classroom. Mr. Nolan knocks on the door and enters. MR. NOLAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me. May we have a word, Mr.  Keating?  KEATING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Certainly. Keating fixes his tie and follows Mr. Nolan into the clas MR. NOLAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This was my first classroom, John. Did  you know that? My first desk.  KEATING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't know you taught, Mr. Nolan.  MR. NOLAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: English. Oh, long before your time. It  was hard giving it up, I can tell you.  I'm hearing rumors, John, about some  unorthodox teaching methods in your  classroom. I'm not saying they've  anything to do with the Dalton boy's  outburst. But I don't think I have to  warn you boys his age are very  impressionable.  KEATING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, your reprimand made quite an  impression, I'm sure.  MR. NOLAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was going on in the courtyard the  other day?  KEATING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Courtyard?  MR. NOLAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Boys marching, clapping in unison.  KEATING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, that. That was an exercise to prove  a point. Dangers of conformity.  MR. NOLAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, John, the curriculum here is set.  It's proven it works. If you question,  what's to prevent them from doing the  same?  KEATING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I always thought the idea of educating  was to learn to think for yourself.  MR. NOLAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At these boys' ages? Not on your life!  Tradition, John. Discipline. Prepare  them for college, and the rest will take  care of itself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie sits with his bongos as the other boys are all cr around him. He hits the bongoes as he mimes Nolan's foots CHARLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Creak. He started walking around towards  my left. Creak. Creak. "Assume the  position, Mr. Dalton." The door opens and Keating walks in. Many of the boys get their seats. KEATING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all right, gentlemen.  CHARLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Keating.  KEATING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Dalton. That was a pretty lame stunt  you pulled today.  CHARLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're siding with Mr. Nolan? What about  Carpe diem and sucking all the marrow  out of life and all that?  KEATING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sucking the marrow out of life doesn't  mean choking on the bone. Sure there's a  time for daring and there's a time for  caution, and a wise man understands  which is called for.  CHARLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I thought you'd like that.  KEATING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. You being expelled from school is  not daring to me. It's stupid, 'cause  you'll miss some golden opportunities.  CHARLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Like what?  KEATING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like, if nothing else, the opportunity  to attend my classes. Got it, Ace?  CHARLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aye, aye, Captain.  KEATING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep your head about you. That goes for  the lot of you.  BOYS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Captain.  KEATING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phone call from God. If it had been  collect, it wouldn't been daring. Keating leaves and the boys gather around Charlie once ag CHARLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. Go on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neil bikes away as the clock bell tolls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neil walks into the back of the theater and watches vario actors rehearsing on stage. A smile fills his face. DIRECTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're trying to rehearse, okay? Start.  LYSANDER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A good persuasion, therefore hear me,  Hermia.  DIRECTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait, please. Excitement. I don't hear  any excitement about this play. And take  her hand. Bring her down the stage and  stop. And "There, gentle Hermia." Okay?  Try again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bell rings and students rush down the hall. BOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's for dinner?  PITTS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spaghetti and meatballs! Neil comes up the stairs as everyone else swarms down to NEIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Save some for me. "But, room, Fairy!  Here comes Oberon." Neil opens the door to his room and sees his father sitti NEIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father.  MR. PERRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neil.  NEIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute. Before you say anything,  please let me ex- Mr. Perry rises from the desk. MR. PERRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you dare talk back to me! It's bad  enough that you've wasted your time with  this, this absurd acting business. But  you deliberately deceived me! How, how,  how did you expect to get away with  this? Answer me. Who put you up to it?  Was it this new man? This, uh, Mr.  Keating?  NEIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Nobody-- I thought I'd surprise you.  I've gotten all A's in every class.  MR. PERRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you think I wasn't going to find  out? "Oh, my niece is in a play with  your son," says Mrs. Marks. "No, no,  no," I say, "you must be mistaken. My  son's not in a play." You made me a liar  of me, Neil! Now, tomorrow you go to  them and you tell them that you're  quitting.  NEIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I can't. I have the main part. The  performance is tomorrow night.  MR. PERRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care if the world comes to an  end tomorrow night. You are through with  that play. Is that clear? Is that clear?  NEIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.  Mr. Perry goes to leave and then turns around. MR. PERRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I made a great many sacrifices to get  you here, Neil, and you will not let me  down.  NEIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keating is seated at his desk. He is writing a letter and looks up at the framed photo on his desk of a woman playi There is a knock at the door. KEATING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's open. Neil enters and closes the door behind him. He appears to KEATING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neil, what's up?  NEIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I speak to you a minute?  KEATING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Certainly. Sit down. Neil goes to take a seat but notices the chair is piled u Neil picks them up and Keating gets up from his seat to h NEIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. Here.  KEATING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me. Get you some tea?  NEIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tea. Sure. Keating goes to a table in the corner and begins pouring KEATING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like some milk or sugar in that?  NEIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, thanks.  NEIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gosh, they don't give you much room  around here.  KEATING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it's part of the monastic oath. They  don't want worldly things distracting me  from my teaching. Keating gives Neil a cup of tea and they return to their looks at the photo on the desk. NEIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's pretty.  KEATING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's also in London. Makes it a little  difficult.  NEIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can you stand it?  KEATING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stand what?  NEIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can go anywhere. You can do  anything. How can you stand being here?  KEATING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Cause I love teaching. I don't wanna be  anywhere else.  KEATING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's up?  NEIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just talked to my father. He's making  me quit the play at Henley Hall.  Acting's everything to me. I-- But he  doesn't know. He-- I can see his point.  We're not a rich family like Charlie's,  and we-- But he's planning the rest of  my life for me, and I-- H-He's never  asked me what I want.  KEATING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you ever told your father what you  just told me? About your passion for  acting. You ever show him that?  NEIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't.  KEATING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?  NEIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't talk to him this way.  KEATING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you're acting for him, too. You're  playing the part of the dutiful son. I  know this sounds impossible, but you  have to talk to him. You have to show  him who you are, what your heart is.  NEIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know what he'll say. He'll tell me  that acting's a whim, and I should  forget it. That how they're counting on  me. He'll just tell me to put it out of  my mind, "for my own good."  KEATING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are not an indentured servant. If  it's not a whim for you, you prove it to  him by your conviction and your passion.  You show him that And if he still  doesn't believe you, well, by then  you'll be out of school and you can do  anything you want.  A tear falls down Neil's cheek and he wipes it away. NEIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. What about the play? The show's  tomorrow night.  KEATING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you have to talk to him before  tomorrow night.  NEIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't there an easier way?  KEATING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  NEIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm trapped.  KEATING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you're not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Knox exits one of the doors. The ground is covered with a layer of snow. He looks around to see if anyone is about hurries over to the bike rack. grabbing one of the bikes, off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A crowd of students come in from the cold. Knox pushes hi them, carrying a handful of wildflowers. He begins search KNOX

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris! He approaches a girl with hair similar to Chris' and turn only to realize that it's not her. KNOX

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris Noel. Do you know where she is?  GIRL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um, I think she's in room 111. The girl points down the hallway and Knox sets off in tha KNOX

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. Chris is at her locker talking to a friend. She just clos as she notices Knox coming towards her. She turns away. KNOX

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me. Chris.  CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Knox, what are you doing here?  KNOX

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I came to apologize for the other night.  I brought you these and a poem I wrote  for you. Chris pulls him aside, out of the main hallway. CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Knox, don't you know that, if Chet finds  you here he'll kill you?  KNOX

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't care. I love you, Chris.  CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Knox, you're crazy.  KNOX

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I acted like a jerk and I know it.  Please, accept these. Please.  CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. No-- I, I can't. Forget it. Chris walks away. The school bell rings and she enters he classroom, closing the door behind her. Undaunted, Knox f opening the door and standing before her desk. CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Knox, I don't believe this.  KNOX

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All I'm asking you to do is listen. As Knox begins to read his poem, the classroom grows quie everyone stops to listen. KNOX

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The heavens made a girl named Chris  With hair and skin of gold.  To touch her would be paradise. Chris holds her head in her hands in embarrassment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Knox sneaks in through a side door. He snatches a slice o from the counter and motions to one of the staff to keep He then begins to eat the toast as he hurries away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The school bell rings and Knox pushes his way up the stai the slower students. At the top he joins the other boys w are grabbing their books. CHARLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get out of here. Cameron, you fool. Charlie notices Knox and grabs his jacket. CHARLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, how'd it go? Did you read it to her?  KNOX

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. The boys begin to get all excited but Charlie shushes the PITTS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd she say?  KNOX

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing.  CHARLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing. What do you mean, nothing?  KNOX

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing. But I did it. Knox walks away down the hall and the others chase after CHARLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did she say? I know she had to say  something.  PITTS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come here, Knox.  KNOX

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seize the day!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keating walks from the front of the classroom to Neil's d is the only student remaining in the class. KEATING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you talk to your father?  NEIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, he didn't like it one bit, but at  least he's letting me stay in the play.  He won't be able to make, make it. He's  in Chicago. But, uh, I think he's gonna  let me stay with acting.  KEATING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? You told him what you told me?  NEIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. He wasn't happy. But he'll be gone  at least four days. I don't think he'll  make the show, but I think he'll let me  stay with it. "Keep up the school work."  Thanks. Neil picks up his books and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys are grooming themselves in front of the mirrors. PITTS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beautiful baby.  MEEKS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beautiful baby. Henley Hall, here I  come.  CAMERON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, just a moment. Yes. You're so  cute. Cameron runs a comb through his hair and Todd tries to me CAMERON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Todd. I'm trying to fix  this.  TODD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Nuwanda. You're gonna miss  Neil's entrance.  PITTS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He said something about getting red  before we left.  CAMERON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Getting red? What does that mean?  PITTS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I, uh-- Well, you know Charlie. One of the stalls opens and Charlie's hand emerges, holdi brush and a bottle of red paint. CAMERON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, Charlie, what's this "getting red"  bit? Charlie opens his unbuttoned shirt to show a large red li painted down his chest. TODD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: W-What is that?  CHARLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's an Indian warrior symbol for  virility. Makes me feel potent, like it  can drive girls crazy. Charlie buttons up his shirt as everyone prepares to leav TODD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, come on, Charlie. The girls are  waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys are walking down the hall to leave. Cameron stop The other boys notice and stop as well. Charlie softly wh standing by the door. Knox stares at her in surprise KNOX

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris. Knox leaves the other boys to join her. KNOX

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing here?  KEATING (O.S.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, let's go.  KNOX

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead, guys. I'll catch up.  CHARLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, come on, guys. Charlie hustles the boys away. Meeks remains staring at h returns to drag him away. KNOX

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris, you can't be in here. I-If they  catch you, we're both gonna be in big  trouble.  CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, but it's fine-- Knox shushes her and leads her out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Snow is lightly falling as Chris and Knox walk outside. CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's fine for you to come barging into  my school and make a complete fool out  of me?  KNOX

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't mean to make a fool out of you.  CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you did. Chet found out. And it  took everything I could do to keep him  from coming here and killing you. Knox,  you have got to stop this stuff.  KNOX

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't, Chris. I love you.  CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Knox, you say that over and over. You  don't, you don't even know me.  Keating calls out from a nearby car. KEATING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you be joining us, Mr. Overstreet? KNOX

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead, Captain. I'll walk.  CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Knox, Knox, it just so happens that I  could care less about you?  KNOX

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you wouldn't be here warning me  about Chet.  CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to go. I'm gonna be late for the  play.  KNOX

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you going with him?  CHRIS (laughs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chet? To a play? Are you kidding?  KNOX

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then come with me.  CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Knox, you are so infuriating.  KNOX

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Chris. Just give me one chance.  If you don't like me after tonight, I'll  stay away forever.  CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.  KNOX

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I promise. Dead Poets Honor. You come  with me tonight. And then, if you don't  want to see me again, I swear I'll bow  out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what would happen if Chet found  out?  KNOX

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He won't know anything. We'll sit in the  back and sneak away as soon as it's  over.  CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I suppose you would promise that  this would be the end of it.  KNOX

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dead Poets Honor.  CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is that?  KNOX

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My word. Chris walks away from him and then turns to face him. CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are so infuriating. Chris gestures for Knox to follow her. Charlie does a lit twirl as he joins her and puts his arm around her. They w

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The audience is packed. The stage is set up to resemble a lights dance about it. From behind a bush, Neil emerges, crown of twigs and berries and twigs on his hands. In the Charlie emerges from his seat, all excited. CHARLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, there he is! Hey, hey. Cameron shoves him back into his seat. KEATING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shh, boys. On stage, Neil hides behind a tree as a girl emerges, sim but with flowers in her hair. Neil sneaks over to the gir FAIRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Either I mistake your shape and making  quite,  Or else you are that shrewd and knavish  sprite  Call'd Robin Goodfellow:  PUCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thou speak'st aright; In the audience, Chris and Knox enter and are shown to se PUCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am that merry wanderer of the night.  I jest to Oberon and make him smile  When I a fat and bean-fed horse beguile, Puck makes horse sounds and the audience laughs. PUCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neighing in likeness of a filly foal:  And sometime lurk I in a gossip's bowl,  In very likeness of a roasted crab,  And when she drinks, against her lips I  bob  And on her wither'd dewlap pour the ale.  The wisest aunt, telling the saddest  tale, In the audience, Charlie leans over towards Keating. CHARLIE (whispering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's good. He's really good. Keating gives a thumbs up. PUCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometime for three-foot stool mistaketh  me;  Then slip I from her bum, down topples  she,  And "tailor" cries, and falls into a  cough;  And then the whole quire hold their hips  and laugh,  And waxen in their mirth and neeze and  swear  A merrier hour was never wasted there.  But, room, Fairy! here comes Oberon.  FAIRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And here my mistress. Would that he were  gone! The two actors hide behind the trees, lifting their twig hands to hide themselves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two other actors are onstage.  LYSANDER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then by your side no bed-room me deny;  For lying so, Hermia, I do not lie  HERMIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lysander riddles very prettily:  Now much beshrew my manners and my  pride,  If Hermia meant to say Lysander lied.  But, gentle friend, for love and  courtesy  Lie further off; in human modesty,  Such separation as may well be said  Becomes a virtuous bachelor and a maid,  and, good night, sweet friend:  Thy love ne'er alter till thy sweet life  end! Neil is watching the actors from the wing. He glances out and sees his father enter the back of the theater. Neil b the shadows. LYSANDER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amen, amen, to that fair prayer, say I; The director breaks Neil out of his thoughts. DIRECTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neil. That's your cue, Neil. Come on,  Neil. Here's your crown. Let's go. Neil reluctantly replaces his crown and follows her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On stage, Neil collects dew in a leaf and holds it over h fairies dance about. In the audience, Knox takes Chris' h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The stage is dark. A spotlight comes on to reveal Neil wi the audience. He slowly turns around to face the audience PUCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we shadows have offended, Neil directs his eyes at his father, who stills stands at of the theater. PUCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Think but this, and all is mended,  That you have but slumber'd here  While these visions did appear.  And this weak and idle theme,  No more yielding but a dream,  Gentles, do not reprehend:  If you pardon, we will mend:  And, as I am an honest Puck,  If we have unearned luck  Now to 'scape the serpent's tongue,  We will make amends ere long;  Else the Puck a liar call;  So, good night unto you all.  Give me your hands, if we be friends,  And Robin shall restore amends. Neil backs away and the curtains close as the audience be applaud enthusiastically. Behind the curtain numerous peo congratulate Neil as they line up for the curtain call. T open. Charlie and the other boys rise to their feet, foll by the rest of the audience. The actors bow to continued actors push Neil forward and he takes a second bow. BOYS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yawp!  KNOX

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, Neil! The curtain closes again and Neil turns around, letting o excited sigh. Various actors continue to congratulate him lets out a yell as he walks offstage. In the audience, wh are leaving, Mr. Perry approaches a woman. MR. PERRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, I'm Neil's father. I need to  see him. Backstage, the woman approaches Neil. WOMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neil, Your father. He's- Neil nods in agreement. ACTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you think? WOMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really I thought you were all just  wonderful! Neil emerges from the curtains, carrying his costume. The nearly empty now, except for Mr. Perry standing at the ba smiles at him but the smile quickly disappears.
